questions.question: What seems to motivate Abigail's actions in Act I?

choices.answer: jealousy and the desire for power over others
her wish to leave Salem
the desire to protect her uncle and help Betty
devout faith and deep-seated superstition

questions.question: During this time period, married women were referred to as:

choices.answer: Mrs.
Madam
Goody
Poor thing

questions.question: This play was written as a response to:

choices.answer: The Great Depression and WW2
The Red Scare/McCarthyism
His bitter divorce with Marilyn Monroe

questions.question: Children in Salem had to "walk straight, eyes lowered." What kind of life do you think they had?

choices.answer: educated
wild
joyless
joyful

questions.question: What is the setting of The Crucible?

choices.answer: Salem, Massachusetts, today
Salem, Massachusetts, 1600's
Boston, Massachusetts, 1700's
England in the 1600's

questions.question: Rev Parris's main reason for his concern about his daughter?

choices.answer: fear that his daughter will lose her soul
fear that his daughter is dying
fear he will become ill
fear for his reputation

questions.question: What is the "poppet" that appears in Act II?

choices.answer: A doll
evidence that one is religious
a tool for witchcraft
a puppet

questions.question: What is the setting of Act IV?

choices.answer: the Proctors' home
the Salem jail
the woods outside of town
the judge's chambers

questions.question: How does Elizabeth show that she understands John at the end of Act IV?

choices.answer: She pleads not to be present at his execution.
She demands he confess so they both may live.
She knows honor is more important to him than his life.
She asks that he forgive her.

questions.question: In Act I, why does John Proctor feel guilty about Abigail?

choices.answer: He had an affair with her.
He accused her of witchcraft.
He fired her.
He threw her out of the church.

questions.question: In Act I, which of the young women has the most influence over the others?

choices.answer: Mary Warren
Tituba
Elizabeth Proctor
Abigail Williams

questions.question: In Act II, what is the source of the conflict between Elizabeth and John?

choices.answer: Elizabeth suspects that John has been unfaithful.
The two suspect each other of witchcraft.
John was unfaithful, she has not forgiven him.
They are tired of each other.

questions.question: What do Tituba's words and the stage directions tell us about Puritan's attitudes towards their slaves?

choices.answer: They believed slaves were likely to rebel.
They believed slaves were their equals.
They believed slaves should be freed.
They believed slaves were uncivilized.

questions.question: What sad and frightening reason drives Mrs. Putnam to hunt for witches in Salem?

choices.answer: her desire to speak to the dead
anger at her husband
the deaths of seven of her babies
anger at John Proctor

questions.question: Why does Proctor think Abigail accuses his wife of witchcraft in Act II?

choices.answer: to punish Proctor for rejecting her
to show Salem how much power she has
to punish Elizabeth for being a bad boss
to distract from her own witchcraft

questions.question: What does Proctor mean when he states, "no matter what I do, an everlasting funeral marches" around Elizabeth's heart?

choices.answer: He wants to move away from Salem, but she does not.
She is always unhappy with him, whatever he does.
She does not want a cow as a gift.
He fears she wishes he were dead.

questions.question: From the rising action of Act I, what can you predict Abigail is most likely to do?

choices.answer: fight for her uncle's reputation
try to implicate Elizabeth as a witch
help Tituba avoid trouble
fall in love with Rev Hale

questions.question: Why is Giles Corey's refusal to name names important in        Act III?

choices.answer: It shows him to be guilty of non-cooperation.
It shows that he does not have as much knowledge as he thought.
It shows that he is the one who acts honorable, not the court.
It shows how much he dislikes Thomas Putnam.

questions.question: What is Proctor suggesting about Mary Warren when he says, "It is strange work for a Christian girl to hang old women."

choices.answer: Mary has become as powerful as Abigail.
Mary is leaving the church
Mary is religious
Mary is dangerous and should rethink her actions.

questions.question: Proctor says he "is striving against his disgust with Hale and with himself for even answering." What does this tell us

choices.answer: He has answers but hides them
He does not have the answers he needs.
His feelings for Hale are respectful
He is in conflict not just with Hale but also with himself.

questions.question: Why is Abigail's testimony in Act III an example of dramatic irony?

choices.answer: The audience is unaware of Abigail's true character
The audience realizes Abigail has become a better person
Audience expects Abigail to accuse Mary of being a witch, but she doesn't
The audience is aware of Abigail's true character but Danforth is not

questions.question: Why does John Proctor bring Mary Warren to court in Act III?

choices.answer: to show that Parris is a fraud
to prove he does not believe in witches
to save Elizabeth from judgement
to prove the court is not a just court

questions.question: Danforth plans to execute prisoners quickly. What theme about the use of the law might be suggested and also applied now

choices.answer: justice is served by quick sentencing
laws are made to be broken
The law is not always just
judges must act quickly in all cases

questions.question: Why does Danforth treat Parris with contempt in Act IV?

choices.answer: He thinks Parris wants to get rich
He thinks Parris cares only for himself
He thinks Parris is a fool to believe Abigail
He thinks Parris is committed to Mercy

questions.question: In Act III, which of the following characters unknowingly does harm by cooperating in an unjust process?

choices.answer: John Proctor
Ezekiel Cheever
Reverend Parris
Mary Warren

questions.question: This person was known as a model citizen and a person of great faith

choices.answer: John Proctor
Ann Putnam
Giles Corey
Rebecca Nurse

questions.question: In Act III, Danforth makes a logical fallacy through his premise that we must trust the victims. Why does he say this?

choices.answer: witches are tricky
children always tell the truth
Because a witch will never confess

questions.question: Which event serves as the climax in Act IV?

choices.answer: Parris's plea to Elizabeth
Abigail's disappearance from Salem
Elizabeth's plea to John
John's refusal to sign the confession

questions.question: What key message or theme does John's destruction of the confession convey?

choices.answer: Individuals are stronger than courts
One's honor cannot be signed away
justice can be assured with documents
Forgiveness is found even in courtrooms

questions.question: This play is set in:

choices.answer: Boston-1597
Salem- 1692
Plymouth- 1663
Salem- 1909
